Trade Kings Group is a privately owned Zambian fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) and manufacturing conglomerate founded in 1995. It is among the largest FMCG manufacturers in Sub-Saharan Africa, offering over 91 brands and 1,700 SKUs across categories such as home care, personal care, confectionery, baked goods, beverages, dairy, and steel.
As of 2022, the company employs more than 16,000 people and generated approximately US$700 million in annual turnover, with operations in nine countries and manufacturing facilities in Zambia and Zimbabwe.
The group is known for its flagship Boom Detergent brand and has made substantial capital investments, including a US$40 million detergent plant in the Lusaka South Multi-Facility Economic Zone, as well as plans to build Zambia’s largest plastic recycling facility.
Subsidiaries
BigTree Beverages
BigTree Beverages is a subsidiary of Trade Kings Group, established in 2016, and has rapidly become one of Zambia’s largest beverage companies. In June 2022, the company invested US$80 million into a state-of-the-art beverage production facility located in the Lusaka South Multi-Facility Economic Zone. This investment encompassed advanced technology, research and development, and infrastructure enhancements, significantly increasing production volumes to meet both domestic and regional demand. As of 2022, BigTree Beverages supplies its products to ten countries across Sub-Saharan Africa, offering a diverse portfolio that includes:

This strategic expansion underscores BigTree Beverages’ commitment to innovation and quality, aligning with Trade Kings Group’s vision of industrial growth and regional market leadership.
KingsWorth Group Limited
In October 2025, Trade Kings Group inaugurated Zambia’s first glucose and starch manufacturing facility under its subsidiary, KingsWorth Group Limited (KGL), located in the Lusaka South Multi-Facility Economic Zone. The US$110 million plant, launched by President Hakainde Hichilema, positions Zambia as the third producer of glucose and starch in Africa, following Egypt and South Africa. The facility is designed to process 126,000 tonnes of maize annually, producing glucose, starch, maltodextrin, and animal feed by-products. This development aims to reduce Zambia’s reliance on imports, bolster local agriculture by sourcing maize from local farmers, and create over 1,000 direct jobs, contributing significantly to the nation’s industrialization and economic transformation.
History
Trade Kings Group was founded in 1995 by Mohamed Iqbal Patel, originally operating from a small garage in Lusaka, Zambia, where it produced Blue Boom Detergent Paste. The company's early years saw it diversify into toilet soaps in 1997 and confectionery by 1998.
In 2005, Trade Kings expanded into South Africa by establishing a subsidiary that initially imported confectionery before setting up a manufacturing plant in Johannesburg in 2009. By 2006, it had launched multiple food brands—including Amazon confectionery, Swiss Bake, Big Tree Brands, Yoyo snacks, and Nyama Soya—broadening its FMCG footprint.
A major vertical integration milestone occurred in 2008 with the commissioning of the Kafue Steel Mills (UMCIL), Zambia's first fully integrated facility converting iron ore into finished steel.
In 2018, Trade Kings commissioned a US $40 million detergent manufacturing plant in the Lusaka South Multi-Facility Economic Zone—the largest of its kind in Sub‑Saharan Africa—aimed at curbing cheap imports and boosting local production.
By the early 2020s, the group had grown into a region-wide FMCG leader with over 90 brands, manufacturing operations in Zambia and Zimbabwe, and exports to multiple countries, including Malawi, Botswana, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and South Africa.
Trade Kings has been recognized by independent publications as a leader in Africa’s industrial growth, with particular emphasis on its manufacturing scale and regional economic contributions.
